0618680004|1.0|Mr. Dawkins prides himself on being an \\"intellectually satisfied atheist\\" however what he fails to realize is that intellectual satisfaction doesn't amount to anything if one is spiritually dead.  He seems to be stuck in a 200 year-old mindset, harking back to a time when the scientific and religious views of the world were actively antagonistic and wholly incompatible-- even going so far as to claim that modern science has provided a basis for dismissing both God and religion altogether.<br /><br />And yet, apparently unbeknownst to him, many of the elite scientists of the last 100 years-- Planck, Heisenberg, de Broglie, Einstein, Oppenheimer, Schrodinger, Eddington, Jeans, Pauli, Davies, and many others-- actively endorsed an underlying religious/mystical point of view as the essential backbone of a good scientist, were acutely aware of the inability of the scientific method to answer the deeper metaphysical questions or provide anything close to a complete account of reality and, in many cases, saw their scientific work as, while not vindicating religion per se, decidedly making it possible for a scientific picture of the world to be /consistent/ with it.  Science can tell us about the laws that operate in the external world, but it can say nothing at all about who we really are, whence we came, whither we are going and to what we owe the drive within us for knowledge and understanding that underlies all scientific endeavour and is the true seat and source of all religious experience.  Natural science deals exclusively with the objective external world.  This means that it is powerless in principle to explain our subjective conscious awareness, the one thing we can't be skeptical of and the ultimate source of all religious feeling, experience and spiritual understanding.  This very sentiment once prompted none other than Erwin Schrodinger to lament that \\"the scientific picture of the real world around me is very deficient. It gives a lot of factual information, puts all our experience in a magnificently consistent order, but it is ghastly silent about all and sundry that is really near to our heart, that really matters to us\\".  Science is a powerful tool, no doubt, but it can at most tell us a fraction of the story.  The other, arguably the more important half-- which consists of an inner world of self-consciousness, conscience, beauty, form and spiritual yearning-- is fundamentally subjective and therefore strictly outside the scope of natural science.  This isn't to say that the two are necessarily at odds--far from it--rather, both are necessary for a complete picture.  Einstein himself, who wrote often that the \\"cosmic religious feeling\\" was the ultimate motivator for any true scientist once stated that \\"religion without science is lame, science without religion is blind\\".<br /><br />Regarding Dawkins' claims that science has rendered religion obsolete, consider the following words of Max Planck, founder of quantum theory, spoken during his Nobel Prize acceptance speech: \\"As a man who has devoted his whole life to the most clear-headed science, to the study of matter, I can tell you as a result of my research into atoms this much. There is no matter, as such. All matter originates and exists only by virtue of a force which brings the particles of the atom to vibration. I must assume behind this force the existence of a conscious and intelligent mind. This mind is the matrix of all matter\\" and the following passage by Cambridge physicist Sir James Jeans: \\"Today there is a wide measure of agreement which, on the physical side of science, approaches almost to unanimity that the stream of knowledge is heading towards a non-mechanical reality; the universe begins to look more like a great thought than a great machine. Mind no longer appears as an accidental intruder into the realm of matter; we are beginning to suspect that we ought rather to hail it as the creator and governor of the realm of matter-- not, of course, our individual minds, but the mind in which the atoms out of which our individual minds have grown to exist as thoughts...The new knowledge compels us to revise our hasty first impressions that we had stumbled into a universe which either did not concern itself with life or was actively hostile to life. The old dualism of mind and matter, which was mainly responsible for the supposed hostility, seems likely to disappear, not through matter becoming in any way more shadowy or insubstantial than heretofore, or through mind becoming resolved into a function of the working of matter, but through substantial matter resolving itself into a creation and manifestation of mind.\\"  Hardly words of men who feel they are putting nails in the coffin of religion, and it's going to take more than the aggressive fanaticism Richard Dawkins to convince me otherwise.<br /><br />Dawkins wants us to believe that evolutionary theory gives us reason to dismiss the notion of an underlying intelligence to nature.  That's ridiculous.  For one thing, to echo David Berlinski's sentiment, not even a thimble can come into being without the aid of intelligent guidance-- why should the most efficient and complex structures in existence in the universe be any different?  This statement, though rhetorically compelling, doesn't settle the issue-- but fear not, despite what Dawkins would have you believe, the intelligent design theorists are precisely correct when they observe that the developments in biology throughout the last 50 years, with the revealing of complex cellular machines, layer after layer of irreducible complexity and the unfathomable magnitude of genetic information required for DNA to function overwhelmingly speak against the fundamental Darwinian assumption that evolution is an ultimately blind and unguided process.  That Dawkins, a man who is regarded by many as an important spokesperson for the scientific community, can fail utterly to see this, in spite of the numerous gaping holes that have been repeatedly poked through all of his arguments and that, regarding religion, he can speak so arrogantly, aggressively and above all dismissively about matters (and no light matters at that) where his understanding is so profoundly shallow and spurious-- is frightening, irritating and downright shameful.<br /><br />I will close with a quote from philosopher Thomas Nagel that I feel is especially pertinent here:<br /><br />\\"I speak from experience, being strongly subject to this fear myself: I want atheism to be true and am made uneasy by the fact that some of the most intelligent and well-informed people I know are religious believers. It isn't just that I don't believe in God and, naturally, hope that I'm right in my belief. It's that I hope there is no God! I don't want there to be a God; I don't want the universe to be like that...[Fear of religion may be] responsible for much of the scientism and reductionism of our time.\\", but the mind in which the atoms out of which our individual minds have grown to exist as thoughts...The new knowledge compels us to revise our hasty first impressions that we had stumbled into a universe which either did not concern itself with life or was actively hostile to life. The old dualism of mind and matter, which was mainly responsible for the supposed hostility, seems likely to disappear, not through matter becoming in any way more shadowy or insubstantial than heretofore, or through mind becoming resolved into a function of the working of matter, but through substantial matter resolving itself into a creation and manifestation of mind.\\"  Hardly words of men who feel they are putting nails in the coffin of religion, and it's going to take more than the aggressive fanaticism Richard Dawkins to convince me otherwise.      Dawkins wants us to believe that evolutionary theory gives us reason to dismiss the notion of an underlying intelligence to nature.  That's ridiculous.  For one thing, to echo David Berlinski's sentiment, not even a thimble can come into being without the aid of intelligent guidance-- why should the most efficient and complex structures in existence in the universe be any different?  This statement, though rhetorically compelling, doesn't settle the issue-- but fear not, despite what Dawkins would have you believe, the intelligent design theorists are precisely correct when they observe that the developments in biology throughout the last 50 years, with the revealing of complex cellular machines, layer after layer of irreducible complexity and the unfathomable magnitude of genetic information required for DNA to function overwhelmingly speak against the fundamental Darwinian assumption that evolution is an ultimately blind and unguided process.  That Dawkins, a man who is regarded by many as an important spokesperson for the scientific community, can fail utterly to see this, in spite of the numerous gaping holes that have been repeatedly poked through all of his arguments and that, regarding religion, he can speak so arrogantly, aggressively and above all dismissively about matters (and no light matters at that) where his understanding is so profoundly shallow and spurious-- is frightening, irritating and downright shameful.      I will close with a quote from philosopher Thomas Nagel that I feel is especially pertinent here:    \\"I speak from experience, being strongly subject to this fear myself: I want atheism to be true and am made uneasy by the fact that some of the most intelligent and well-informed people I know are religious believers. It isn't just that I don't believe in God and, naturally, hope that I'm right in my belief. It's that I hope there is no God! I don't want there to be a God; I don't want the universe to be like that...[Fear of religion may be] responsible for much of the scientism and reductionism of our time.\\"

B000002G7G|5.0|Although not quite as utterly phenomenal as their peerless debut, and hardly comparable to the abrasive sonic assault of White Light/White Heat, the Velvet's epynomous third album does indeed stand up on its understated, simple, yet hauntingly poignant set of folk and garage inspired rock/pop. Despite their avant-garde inclinations, most of Lou Reed and Co's (of course this being the first album without John Cale) songs were still elementally 'pop' - with recogniseable song structures, melodies.etc. This probably refines and simplifies that which was glimpsed at in the Velvet Underground and Nico.  <br /> <br />It is a credit to the consistent high quality of this album that there are no REAL standouts, like in other albums of the era (the Doors great debut comes to mind, despite its overall greatness). 'Candy Says' is an absolute chestnut - few songs are as poignant, yet as relievingly unsentimental. Then there's 'What Goes On', Some Kinds of Love, Jesus. Murder Mystery is probably a bit over the top, and can get too long after awhile, while the others continue the general theme - that between raw underground rock'n'roll, and folk dipped in black tar, a faithful document of the avant-garde underground of 60s New York.

0316172324|4.0|The Salon review of this book makes a remark that Gladwell's mission is to be entertaining, and not useful. I think that if you read this book in the spirit of that remark, you will not be disappointed.<br /><br />Blink is a great book to while away a few hours on a plane or train without feeling as though you are killing your brain cells with junk reading. It has the effect of listening to a really gifted cocktail party conversationalist string together a number of smart stories in search of a common theme. It doesn't quite work, but it is really impressive when it lasts, and darned fun to listen.<br /><br />Blink is amiable and entertaining. It admittedly fails to really build a case for a cohesive scientific thesis on thin slicing and subconscious decision-making. However, given its slim 254 pages and the wide range of stories that it contains, I would argue that it was always meant to give an impression of the subject rather than to be conclusive.<br /><br />Like I said, a good read if you go in expecting the right things.
B00003CXWV|4.0|Blow portrays the life and times of one George Jung, a real-life drug dealer currently serving a long prison sentence and not eligible for parole until 2015.  Ted Demme presents Jung's life as a series of montages, growing up in Massashusetts son of a hard-working man and a shrewish wife, moving to California with a childhood friend and becoming immersed in the marijuana trade, serving a stint in jail and meeting a Columbian who introduces him to cocaine, working his way up in Pablo Escobar's Medellin cartel and making more money than he can spend, betrayal by his colleagues and leaving the business, busted again with large amounts of cocaine in his house during his 38th birthday party, out of jail making amends with his daughter, doing one last job so he can retire to California with his daughter, getting busted yet again and sentenced to 60 years.  It's hard to tell how much of the stroy is real and how much is a product of George Jung's imagination, but in the end Demme had no choice but to trust Jung's portrayal of his life.  To Demme's credit (and maybe Jung's) the movie doesn't deify Jung's life.  He made his decisions for whatever reasons good or bad.  We can guess what his motivations were, and decide whatever we want to about his decisions.  In the end, Jung's life is yet another largely wasted by drugs.  Whatever your opinions are on drugs, this movie's portrayal of Jung's life is largely neutral on the political questions.  That's one reason I rate it so highly.  It doesn't glamorize drugs, nor does it make any judgements on the penalties that Jung ends up getting because of his involvement in the drug trade. <br /> <br />George Jung is played masterfully by Johnny Depp.  Is there any question who is the best actor of his generation?  Depp is brilliant in this movie.  Ray Liotta is superb as Depp's father as well.  The rest of the cast was good except for Penelope Cruz's incoherent portrayal of George Jung's drug addled wife. <br /> <br />The movie coversa lot of ground and lacks some of the detail you might expect because of it.  But it's a well made, thoughtful and haunting movie that will stick with me for awhile. <br /> <br />I definitely recommend this one if you are looking for something a little different than your average Hollywood fare.

B00005JPAD|4.0|\\"You don't make up for your sins in Church; you do it on the street; everything else is __________ and you know it\\"  - from MEAN STREETS (1973) directed by Martin Scorsese        Of all sins - deception proves the most elusive of absolution; for it is through lies and lying that Satan seeks man's ruination. Such is the world of former- seminary-student-turned-film director Martin Scorsese- who has been setting morality fables in brutal urban streets for almost 40 years.        Violent, profane, rife with obsidian-black humor and, as with all Scorsese pictures, set to a soundtrack of classic rock music THE DEPARTED is filled with countless deceitful, plague-carrying rats (both literal and figurative).         Through Scorsese's lens, no one is completely innocent. All characters carry the guilt of mendacity and all must serve a penance. For most this includes blood atonement.        THE DEPARTED, Scorsese's latest meditation on the nature of sin and sinning, unfolds in the rotting bureaus of Irish South Boston and depicts two spies (artists of deception) one working for the police, another working for the mob.        Employing long, sweeping steadicam as well as tracking and crane shots Scorsese's camera bottles lightening with an expert cast working at the top of their collective games. Playing alongside wily veterans Martin Sheen and Alex Baldwin, Leonardo DiCaprio, Matt Damon and Mark Wahlberg all deliver some of their finest, most nuanced work.         Jack Nicholson, playing a graying and wrinkled Satan chews the scenery complete with an authentic \\"Southie\\" accent. Save for couple of scenes in which he gives a grotesque- pain inducing self-parodic imitation of himself, Nicholson reminds us he is one of America's artistic treasures.         And so is director Martin Scorsese, who after stepping away from his comfort zone, returns to his greatest strength- telling contemporary stories about sinners paying for their sins on the streets.

B000065V9Y|3.0|Peter Gabriel was pretty big at the end of the 1980s. In 1986, he released his most commercially successful album, SO, which became a megahit with critics and audiences alike; in 1989, he released PASSION, an expanded version of his soundtrack for Martin Scorsese's controversial 1988 drama THE LAST TEMPTATION OF CHRIST, which is widely considered to be Gabriel's finest achievement. Gabriel fans know that the former Genesis frontman likes to take his time in the studio, and he did take his time in releasing a follow-up to SO. That follow-up was finally released in 1992 as US. It was nowhere near as successful as SO, but over time, fans have come to see US as a gem in the Gabriel catalogue; some even call it his best.  <br /> <br />While SO really didn't have a central concept weaving the songs together, US does: relationships. Around the time that he was working on US, Gabriel was having some major relationship problems. He and his longtime wife Jill, whom he met as a teenager, seperated. He had a turbulent romance with Rosanna Arquette. Reportedly, he even had a brief romance with Sinead O'Connor (whose beautiful voice appears on the first and third tracks of US). To make matters worse, Gabriel's teenage daughter had stopped communicating with him. It wasn't an easy time for Gabriel, and US reflects that. Gabriel bares his heart and soul, working out his emotional problems through his music. Sounds like it would make a great album, doesn't it? It certainly did to me. That's why I was a little taken aback when I decided that US is, in fact, Gabriel's weakest album.  <br /> <br />The album gets off to a great start with the comforting \\"Come Talk To Me\\", inspired by the rift that had appeared between Gabriel and his daughter. It has the tribal drumming found on previous Gabriel albums like SECURITY, as well as the ethereal synthesizers that appeared in songs like \\"In Your Eyes\\". It may be one of Gabriel's best songs, but the subsequent composition, \\"Love To Be Loved\\",is not. The lyrics are simplistic and pointless (the bulk of the song finds Gabriel repeating, \\"I love to be loved\\" - but who doesn't?), and the music is too calm and unoriginal to really excite the listener. That's the problem with many of the songs on US: they just never take off.  <br /> <br />\\"Blood Of Eden\\" is one of the better songs on US. It's about trying to use sex to work through relationship problems. It's during sex that two people are at their closest spiritually, and \\"Blood Of Eden\\" is about a couple trying to get back to that place. After this song, Gabriel does something he's done on just about all of his albums: he throws in a song to lighten things up. On US, that song is \\"Steam\\".  <br /> <br />\\"Steam\\" has been criticized for being nothing but a carbon copy of SO's number one hit \\"Sledgehammer\\". Unfortunately, that's true; people may recognize the same sexually-suggestive lyrics, thick drumming, bouncing guitar, and motown-style horns that made \\"Sledgehammer\\" so great. Still, I don't think people give \\"Steam\\" the credit it deserves. It succeeds in lightening up the album, if only for one song, and it is great fun. I, for one, love it.  <br /> <br />\\"Only Us\\" is another song that never really takes off, followed by what may be the dullest song of Gabriel's career, \\"Washing Of The Water\\". \\"Digging In The Dirt\\", however, is a great song, and possibly the finest on US. The song was written about Gabriel's experiences during psychiatric sessions, during which the psychiatrist apparently dug through the \\"dirt\\" in Gabriel's mind to reveal the emotions trapped within. \\"Digging In The Dirt\\" is a rare and very enjoyable glimpse at Gabriel's dark side, and it really adds some much-needed texture to the album.  <br /> <br />\\"Fourteen Black Paintings\\" is a good, atmospheric song, though at times it feels like a leftover from PASSION. \\"Kiss That Frog\\" is another attempt at lightening the mood, and again, it works. It's one of Gabriel's silliest compositions, butit's undeniably fun. (The odd music video featured some now-cringeworthy CGI and was directed by cult director Brett Leonard.) The album closes on a hopeful note with \\"Secret World\\" (which wound up as the title of Gabriel's second live album), one of the album's better songs.  <br /> <br />Repeated listens reveal that US is far from a bad album, but it can't compare to some of Gabriel's other recordings. The songs all seem sort of muddled, forming a textured album that occasionally teeters on blandness. Luckily, US' highlights are good enough to make up for a few of the less-exciting songs on the album. After the release of US, Gabriel released a 2-CD live recording and then disappeared until briefly surfacing in 2000 to record OVO, the soundtrack to the Millennium Show in London, and then LONG WALK HOME, the soundtrack to RABBIT-PROOF FENCE a few years later. Gabriel didn't release another true album until ten years after the release of US; that album was UP, and it turned out to be one of Gabriel's best recordings. US is Gabriel's weakest album, and though it's not a bad album, I would recommend that you investigate some of Gabriel's other albums first.
0446677450|2.0|RICH DAD, POOR DAD seems contradictory in more than one way:  economically and philosophically.  Probably, Kiyosaki's most inviting, yet deceptive, chapter is Eight, \\"Overcoming obstacles.\\"  Here, he is at his most fervent; one can feel he believes what he is writing is true.  But it is not necessarily true about life itself.<br /><br />Unfortunately, he confuses happiness with the gathering of money--what he calls \\"having money work for you\\"--while you engage in other pleasures of life, even if they are finanacial, also.<br /><br />He assumes people don't like to work to make a living.  There are farmers of all sorts that love their work, artists who thrill at their creations, designers, crafts people--and the list goes on--even though they may or may not be \\"middle class,\\" which he grudgingly \\"respects.\\" There are people who are satisfied to simply have their needs met (including health insurance, a vacation) and no more.<br /><br />In his schemes, he wins, but the other guy or business loses--and in his twisted logic he thinks he has done them a favor.<br /><br />Acquiring money is a \\"game\\" he says, which can be played with some common sense--\\"common sense\\" if you have educated yourself in the field of real estate, finance, his and others' tapes and books and seminars--and aligned yourself with those who already have the my-goal-in-life-is-to-get-rich philosophy.<br /><br />There is a slickness to his humble presentation; I just can't pin it down.  What is amazing about his book (and subsequent ones, I'm told) is that he craftily gives you just enough to want to know more so you will buy follow-up tapes, books, videos and games.  Yet, he sounds so altruistic.<br /><br />Forgive me (no, don't), but I don't really believe there was a rich and poor \\"dad,\\" but that this was his platform on which to organize his book/s.  No way is he going to remember from early childhood what both his \\"dads\\" said to the point of quoting lengthy conversations.  (This point has been made by others, too.)<br /><br />Through most of the book he advocates spending money for both education and investments (especially real estate), but on page 195 he states, \\"The idea that it takes money to make money is the thinking of financially unsophisticated people.\\"  I think I understand the contexts of the former and the latter and this seems a contradiction.  In his opinion, the sophisticated will always TAKE ADVANTAGE (my emphasis)of the lesser sophisticated--this is his mind set.  I don't happen to share this approach to life.  I am a self-made man of comfortable means--rich by no means, and don't have a burning desire to be.<br /><br />Kiyosake (with Sharon Lechter, C.P.A.) is fanning the fires of greed, which he considers a positive and necessary element in becoming rich.  I say let him live his satisfactory life and I'll live mine.  I don't \\"aspire to great wealth\\" (page 105).  There are so many other things to enjoy besides acquiring \\"excessive\\" money.  By his definition I am (almost) one of the losers in life--and that is the point: we all have to define our attitudes about life--I have chosen mine, he his.has been made by others, too.) <br /> <br />Through most of the book he advocates spending money for both education and investments (especially real estate), but on page 195 he states, \\"The idea that it takes money to make money is the thinking of financially unsophisticated people.\\"  I think I understand the contexts of the former and the latter and this seems a contradiction. By his definition I am (almost) one of the losers in life--and that is the point: we all have to define our attitudes about life--I have chosen mine, he his.

B000G759LW|5.0|This is a truly remarkable CD set. It is fairly remarkable to see this diminutive woman and pop phenom known for her slightly raunchy Hip-Hop songs show her true range. From the first time I heard Aguilera several years ago I thought: \\"This woman really has a set of pipes, I wonder if she'll ever begin to explore her full range.\\" Well she has, and the result is wonderful. I have a feeling it must have been infuriating for her to be in the shadow of that Spears chick, the fellow Mouseketeer, who was all package but really didn't have the voice or style to sing anything real in any idiom. Aguilera pays homage to her antecedents; the numbers stylized versions, some deliberately recorded to simulate the kind of \\"in the can\\" sound you encounter when you hear an old Tin Pan Alley classic. Still, these songs remain hers. I am quite astounded. I doubt this album will appeal to many people much over forty. I think even octogenarians would be rocking in their walkers, if they gave it a chance, but that probably won't happen. What I hope is that Aguilera's fan base in their teens and early twenties will be inspired to listen to songs like Dinah Washington's version of \\"Cry Me a River\\" or Billie Holiday's \\"Mean To Me\\" and know where Aguilera is really coming from. Aguilera is a student of the Masters who came before her (she lays this out so well in the Hip-Hop styled intro), yet she can also deliver the goods. It gives me real hope. Not everything in the music business is, in the end, prepackaged, and there are those out there still carrying the torch and passing it on. Kudos to Aguilera! She may be a tiny woman, but she has a giant voice, and a real spirit.

Baker sings on a few tunes, which is okay but no great shakes; on one of them (BORN TO BE BLUE) the focus for the listener is definitely on Bobby Scott's incredibly bluesy piano accompaniment. This is a solid album for Baker, offering up an exciting change and a deeper involvement. Nice!

0393314804|4.0|As other reviewers have noted, Trainspotting is more a collection of short stories than an actual novel. Beyond the gritty surface, Trainspotting is more idea-driven than story-driven, as what ties it all together is the theme of addiction and acceptance.<br /><br />On one level, heroin addiction is portrayed as a symptom of a moribund Scottish working-class, struggling to deal with a post-industrial, post-Thatcher UK. It's telling that the only thing for a healthy person to do in the book is to move to London or out of the country entirely.<br /><br />On another level, heroin addiction is portrayed as a symptom of existential angst. Mark Renton AKA Rent-Boy is a nihilist for whom heroin is simply the most ready-made, prepackaged form of self-negation that he has access to. He fancies himself a martyr for the cause of oblivion, but as he himself attests, this martyrdom is childish, romantic, and entirely ego-centric.<br /><br />I would argue that, in essence, Trainspotting is a coming-of-age story. It deals with a group of young adults who are addicted to self-pity in varying degrees, in this case in the form of heroin. Some of the characters are able to get beyond their own fear and needless self-loathing and become full-fledged human beings. Others are not so lucky; the book is littered with psychic debris. In a more just society, more people might make it, but not everybody. That's life, and nobody can make you choose to live it.

0064409422|5.0|The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe Book Review <br /> The Chronicles of Narnia is a seven book series about the magical land of Narnia. The Lion, he Witch and the Wardrobe is the second book in the series, written by C.S. Lewis. The majority of the story takes place in the magical land of Narnia. The story begins when four siblings, Peter, Susan, Edmund, and Lucy were sent to a professor's house to stay safe during the war. Lucy, the youngest sibling found a wardrobe in the professors house that led to the land of Narnia. As she entered this land, she become acquainted with a friend, Tumnus, and as Edmund approached the land of Narnia, he was acquainted with what he thought was a friend, the Queen, but better known in Narnia as the White Witch. She was trying to take over the King, the Lord of Narnia, known as Aslan. The children realize what is happening with the Witch and Aslan, and defend the King of Narnia. The Witch is conquered and the children decide to stay in the land of Narnia. Many years pass and the children reappear to where they first entered Narnia, and go back through the wardrobe, and realize no time has passed since they left. The story about this land of Narnia continues on in the third book, The Horse and His Boy with reappearances from Edmund, Lucy and Susan. <br /> I enjoyed this book thoroughly. Your attention is caught in the first paragraph, and it is hard for your eyes to drift from the story until you reach the end. There is action, redemption, evil, love, courage, and so much more throughout the course of The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe that every reader is able to enjoy this read. C.S. Lewis does a magnificent job of developing the characters. By the end of the story, you really do care about the well being of the main characters, and have a love and relationship with them. I would suggest every reader to try reading The Chronicles of Narnia, and especially the famous The Lion, the Witch and the Wardrobe. It is an easy read that kids, grownups, males and females should all enjoy. It has an amazing plot with wonderful characters, and is very enjoyable and fun to read.  <br />  <br />

That's right, they were Dissection.<br /><br />I am glad that an essential album like this is rereleased and is receive better distribution. The album is just amazing beyond belief. The late Jon Nodtveidt was one of the greatest guitarists out in the black metal scene. Ole Ohman is a double bass machine! And with the dark feel of a black metal album embedded in their melodic talents, no wonder this album is such a legendary work of art.<br /><br />But wait! There's more! This reissue comes with a bonus disc as well! The first two tracks are a live recording recorded in 1995 but not released until a decade later. Next, we have the band's \\"Into Infinite Obscurity\\" 7\\" covering tracks 3 to 5. Tracks 6 to 9 are the 1992 demo, and track 10  is \\"The Grief Prophecy Demo\\" recorded in 1990. Tracks 3 to 10 are remastered. The final 3 tracks are closing rehearsal tracks from 1990-1991, all remastered as well. And no, they're NOT re-recorded. There's a difference between that and remastering.<br /><br />If you're new to this band, or just love Dissection, pick this up. It's inexpensive and you get a lot out of this reissue. Also, check out the \\"Storm of the Light's Bane\\" reissue as well.

0684803356|5.0|We'll start with the simple ones: sad, deep, bloody...<br /><br />But it's the longer ones that truly sum up the book: thoughtful, emotional, frightening...<br /><br />\\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" starts out simply enough, but it slowly progresses to being a book that houses a series of complex, not entirely predictable characters. Robert Jordan is the main character, an American, often comparing, often thinking. We follow him around in the midst of a not-so-pleasant, frighteningly bloody war. He is accompanied by other men who are either helping him, or have similar tasks, though not all are so. There is Pablo, who in reality, is Jordan's enemy, in that he intends to prevent Jordan from blowing up a certain bridge. There is Pablo's wife, Pilar, who tells a chunk of the book in the form of stories to Jordan about the past. There is Maria, Jordan's crush, and though many concentrate on their love, Maria is a rather flat character, though her history is one that tells more about the surrounding situation.<br /><br />The book itself isn't across that long of a time span, on the other hand it includes many stories that are told to Jordan. The reader is drawn in quickly, and despite the blood, the fear, and the uneasy way everything is written, it's an incredible book. Perhaps it's because of these things; they make the book more realistic and touching to the reader.<br /><br />It is certainly a great book, a wonderful read, and an interesting view on a little known event. It's a good book to read, even if you're not fond of stories with death and blood.

Heck, right out of the box, Jerry Goldsmith's theme alone was gold.<br /><br />And, like all TV on DVD, don't underestimate the \\"commercial-less\\" effect: while a truly bad episode of something will always be a truly bad episode, episodes of \\"Voyager\\" I remember as being mediocre when they were first broadcast now flow better and entertain better now that all the dumb commercials have been removed.  So, episodes I rated in the past as two-star quality now feel like three-star episodes; episodes I remember as rating three-stars before now often feel like three-and-a-half or even four star shows, etc.  It's amazing.<br /><br />But I do agree with the other reviewers that this series' various season-length sets still cost too much.  The high cost especially stands out with this first season, which is quite short.  C'mon, Paramount... don't you want to sell some boxed sets?  Drop those prices!

0618680004|5.0|Unlike his previous book, the magnificent \\"The Ancestor's tale\\", this one isn't a scholarly work. It is written in a conversational tone, and is basically an argument against blind faith and in favor of fact-based reason. Of course, when the writer is of such caliber, no \\"argument\\" is going to be a simple declaration of belief in this and disbelief in that based on a few bits of filmsy evidence. \\"The God Delusion\\" is a veritable broadside of facts, data and analyses, scientific, historical and philosophical, that back Dawkins' point of view.   <br /> <br />The most refreshing aspect of Dawkins' writings on religion is that unlike many of today's agnostics or atheists, he doesn't pay lip service to the respect that is apparently due to the irrartional beliefs of others. That may be deemed a grating trait to many, but it is certainly a honest attitude. Plus, because we have here the example of someone who isn't afraid to call a cat a cat, this books comes across as a breath of fresh air after all the nonsense we've had to endure in the past few years from Intelligent Design advocates and their attempt to bring science education back three hundred years in the name of superstition. <br /> <br />Highly recommended.
B000HDR9NG|5.0|If The Killers' 2004 \\"Hot Fuss\\" album represented the glitz and glamour of Las Vegas - one-night stands, go-go dancers, gratuitous gambling and relationship problems between young adults; then 2006's \\"Sam's Town\\" is the gritty local casino down the road - with its motley crew of locals. If you're a patron of the \\"Hot Fuss\\" casino then you're not going to like travelling the route to \\"Sam's Town\\". However, if you are not necessarily looking for Hot Fuss Part 2, but something still unmistakenly The Killers, this album you will love.  <br /> <br />We start the journey with the title track all ablaze with Brendan Flowers' walls of synth, thumping drums from Ronnie Vannucci, but also a chunky guitar part from Dave Keuning - something that musically sets the scene for the whole album. Here, Flowers greats the listener with the words 'Nobody ever had a dream 'round here...' (but he does of course) then questions 'Why do you waste my time?' in a big chorus, and then 'Have you ever seen the light?'. Flowers is answering his critics while showing them people can rise above their station (he was a former bellhop at the Gold Coast Hotel). The title track ushers in the new more mature Killers; the \\"Sam's Town\\" adult versus the \\"Hot Fuss\\" adolescent.  <br /> <br />The video clip of the first single \\"When You Were Young\\" when placed in the album's context is much more meaningful. It depicts the plight of a naive young woman (in Sam's Town) who fell for the wrong guy. The single is musically an accurate gauge for the rest of the album; prominent guitars with big synth chorus.  <br /> <br />The strangely titled track four is my favourite on the album. 'Bling (Confessions of a King)' is an amazingly constructed song, chugging along at a gallop with a wonderful melody and lyrics. I envision riding my horse in a rush to reach my destination with the wind blowing in my face in order to save my loved one thinking ... 'When I offer you survival, you say its hard enough to live...How do you know that you're right if you're not nervous anymore? It's not so bad, it's not so bad'. And when I think the song can't get any better, it has the most wonderfully uplifting ending with Flowers rising to 'higher and higher - we're gonna take it ... out of the fire, we're gonna make it'. \\"Sam's Town\\" is worth it just for this song.  <br /> <br />The rest of the album doesn't relent either, especially the second single \\"Bones\\". We get a picture of potential lovers frolicking on a nearby river bank to the tune of 'don't you want to feel my bones on your bones?'. With its horns and Flowers' high pitched whine, this track sounds like a Robert Smith (The Cure) pop song circa mid 90's. It just showcases \\"The Killers\\" versatility. It follows the daunting \\"Uncle Johnny\\" with Mark Stoemer's great sliding bass lines (the best I've heard since Tool's song Lateralus). Uncle Johnny has wasted away his life in Sam's Town. This song is another reminder why The Killers are going to sell out stadiums around the world: when I wonder how the song will end a massive chorus of backing vocals hit like an anthem. This album is full of anthems: track 9 \\"My List\\", track 10 \\"This River is Wild\\", and track 11 \\"Why do I Keep Counting?\\" are huge conclusions to Sam's Town and will entertain crowds everywhere.  <br /> <br />The inclusion of the average \\"Where the White Boys Dance\\" detracts from overall product. I don't listen to this song as it is not in the context of the album. Others like it however. <br /> <br />The greatest acts in the history of rock have evolved to shape music and The Killers have manifest into something special. It may not occur, but this album should be the one which catapults this band to be alongside the biggest band in the world - U2, if not superscede them. I didn't actually think The Killers were this good. Brendan Flowers himself said people will be remembering this album in 20 years time, I agree - it is that good.

B000HIVO64|5.0|I admit that my first impression of THE INFORMATION was that Beck had phoned this one in, kinda like a \\"Beck-By-Numbers\\" pastiche. But it only took a few more listens for his fantastic songwriting ability to shine through for me. Beck already merged just about every conceivable music genre on MELLOW GOLD and ODELAY, so it's not really fair to expect him to reinvent the freakin' wheel with every new album.<br /><br />In that respect, THE INFORMATION has less mind-blowing variety than many of his previous efforts, but it's loaded with plenty of great rhythms and beats as can be expected from Beck. There's lots of super-catchy hooks and many of the songs are as good as any he's ever written. Also typical of Beck, there's a lot of sounds and \\"sub-melodies\\" guaranteed to keep the listener intrigued for many a listen. Beck raps all over this album. He's kind of in a rap world of his own - he plays by his own rules. On THE INFORMATION, he moves beyond the white boy self parody bit to rap about anything he wants.<br /><br />Of particular note is the trippy extended final track that morphs repeatedly and reaches a spacey, almost epic peak at the chorus. But it does peter out towards the end, digressing into some spoken word nonsense that can get boring on repeated listens (as spoken word typically does when added to music). That's OK - as I often do, I've made my own copy of this album and I just shaved off the end of that song in a particular place that appealed to me. Considering the interactive direction Beck seems to be headed in, I suspect he would approve.<br /><br />The extra DVD contains the entire album with amusing video shennanigans from Beck and assorted friends. It's fun to have on at a party!<br /><br />As ever, Beck is still an extremely creative musician. THE INFORMATION is further proof and a most worthy addition to any music collection.
B00008NRI7|4.0|\\"Two Weeks Notice\\" is a romantic comedy about Lucy, an idealistic and gutsy Harvard law school graduate (played by Sandra Bullock), who is hired into a prestigious law firm by the firm's jet-setting partner, George (portrayed by Hugh Grant).  George's brother owns the firm. <br /> <br />George enjoys considerable wealth and perks afforded by his position.  He is handsome and rather charming, and he is divorced after philandering.   Lucy and George are direct opposites.  Lucy is from a working, middle class family.  Her mother is a law professor and her father is an attorney with a social conscience.  George seems to have inherited his privileged lot in life.   <br /> <br />Like her father, Lucy is compassionate towards the underdog.  Her latest crusade is an attempt to save a community center located in an aging building.  George's brother wants to demolish this building and replace it with a profitable high-rise. He expects George to close the deal on this project even though George is conflicted because of his increasing  respect and admiration for Lucy.   <br /> <br />When Lucy leaves the law firm in favor of pro bono work, her replacement is a pretty, ambitious, and calculating young Harvard graduate who immediately sets her sights on George.  Complications arise because Lucy has feelings for George and vice versa. <br /> <br />\\"Two Weeks Notice\\" is a competent comedy.  However, to thoroughly appreciate its story, one has to be sympathetic to the lead characters.  Lucy is a person of integrity and conviction.  George only begins to develop these qualities because of his association with Lucy.  For most of the movie, George is a shallow, materialistic womanizer.  It is doubtful that these two would actually end up together. <br /> <br />Still \\"Two Weeks Notice\\" is a fairly pleasant diversion especially if you are fans of Bullock or Grant.  These two talented actors give the movie more appeal than perhaps it deserves.  <br /> <br />

0743298020|4.0|Diane Setterfield has definitely left the gate running with her debut novel 'THE THIRTEENTH TALE'. Not only is the story of mysterious author Vida Winter haunting it is also very well written, a hard combination to come by for a first time novelist.<br /><br />Setterfield tells the story of Margaret an armature biographer who is commissioned to write the biography of Vida Winter a living legend amongst novelists.  Ms winter is not only one of best writers of present day she is also notorious for keeping her past under wraps.  She has made up varying accounts of her history in every interview she has ever conducted and now in her last days she is ready to tell all, with only two conditions...first, the story must be told in order beginning, middle and end and second, no questions may be asked.  Margaret, not sure she is up to the task of writing what will inevitably be a very important piece of work is quickly drawn in to Ms. Winters story when a startling discovery leads her to believe that she and the famous author may have more in common than meets the eye.<br /><br />Vida Winter's story is captivating from the very beginning and will definitely draw the reader in and keep you guessing until the very unpredictable ending.  My only regret about 'THE THIREENTH TALE' was that Margaret's own story was no where near as intriguing and I kept wanting to get back to learning the secrets of Vida Winter.  With that said, Setterfield's novel is definitely worthy of all of the praise it has garnered thus far and she is definitely an author to watch!
0553588486|4.0|Book one of Martin's a Song of Ice and Fire was the only book in this series Martin wrote with the fire, born of artisitic desire. For people familiar with this series, you'll know about Martin's approach to fantasy writing in these books. Going for the shock factor in his stories and painting the morality of his characters whether hero or villain, with a shade of grey.<br /><br />For the new readers and old alike, this book is trully great and I would recommend it to any fantasy fan. However, it would be wise to note that even though a Game of Thrones is a great book, the progressive novels in the series aren't. They range from good to above average, to average if not awful.<br /><br />Their criticisms - for me - stem from an overall lowering of the mystique and appeal of whatever the author seems to envision in the first book, and then a decidedly cheap approach towards unpredictability in his story's plot, by killing and degrading relatively key and interesting characters. He does the killing-off in such a careless manner that the deaths of the said characters, serve no purpose in the narrative, in fact they only leave the remainder of whatever plot there is very bare, with no resolution in sight.<br /><br />Characters formerly potrayed as villains are given more humane motivations without really being compelling and Martin falls into the trap of doing this for almost all of them. Almost as if the characters he killed off were only to make room for said characters, but the overall plot suffers greatly as a result.<br /><br />My comments end here, but for anyone newly introduced to this series just read book one, because the seed of what looked like a fantasy gem, doesn't grow beyond this book. Plus it's better not to have your expectations dashed.

B000BP86OG|4.0|After their debut The Darkness were either going to grow or implode. Luckily they chose the former. This album has had so much attention to detail lavished on it, so much work has been done to ensure every moment was the appropriate Darkness experience.<br /><br />The quirks come in droves, filling this album with lovely touches. And the whole package, from the cover art to the employment of Roy Thomas Baker as producer shows the same effort. With stronger songs the fact that Justin insists on using his high register gimmick voice every darn song grates less but it's still an issue for this listener. But at least The Darkness got people talking again about this style of much maligned hard rock and got a whole new generation into a certain style of music. And annoyed a certain John Bon Jovi (who clearly doesn't get it). Then again his criticism is coming from a guy who built his career on selling power ballads to 15 year old girls. So lighten up John!<br /><br />The good time rock here is a breath of fresh air, just constant pleasant feelings wash over the listener. The way the band have taken some risks here is also worthy of a mention. Musically it is restrained when it needs to be and full blooded hard rock when appropriate. While the live show for this album made it clear that this is the Justin Hawkins show on record that feel is lessened due to the absene of the visual element. Dan Hawkins knows his way around a riff and the more open songs highlight the contribution of the other players.<br /><br />Not quite five stars due to the overuse factor of Justins castrati novelty act vox and the slightly not quite right experiment that is English Country Garden. But overall a great album and as for the whole 'are they serious/are they taking the mickey' - well I couldn't care less. As long as the final result is this good they can have my money
